active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a group discussion, debate the trade-offs between comprehensive audit logging (e.g., unified auditing in Oracle) and performance impacts in a production database during a penetration test. How can pentesters use log review to validate evasion techniques like living-off-the-land?
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in Penetration Testing. Topic: Database Audit Log Review (Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Penetration Testing And Ethical Hacking > Penetration Testing Types > 004_Target-Based Testing Categories > Database Penetration Testing > Database Audit Log Review). Incorporate these pedagogical elements: - Bloom's Taxonomy objectives: [insert learning_objectives array here] - Active learning for reinforcement: [insert active_learning here] - 4-layer scaffolding: [insert scaffolding array here] Use this research context: Database audit logs track events (who, what, when) for incident detection. Key concepts: Auditing, Audit Trail, Unified Auditing (Oracle), Audit Policy. Best practices (completed): Oracle (predefined/custom UNIFIED_AUDIT_POLICY: e.g., CREATE AUDIT POLICY logins ACTIONS LOGIN; SQL Server: CREATE SERVER AUDIT; PostgreSQL: SET log_statement='all'; MySQL: SET global general_log=1). Pentest focus: Review for logged actions/evasion. Standards: CIS Control 8 (https://www.cisecurity.org/controls/audit-log-management), NIST SP 800-92, ISO 27001 Annex A.8.15. Big picture: Post-exploitation in pentest lifecycle. Generate flashcards per schema: [insert flashcard_schema here]. Output as JSON array of objects, each with 'front', 'back' (nested answer/explanation/distractors), 'metadata'. Balance: 20% Layer1/REMEMBER, 25% Layer2/UNDERSTAND, 25% Layer3/APPLY-ANALYZE, 30% Layer4/EVALUATE-CREATE. Ensure distractors are educationally valuable. No duplicates; vary phrasing.
